title: David Rescues Keilah
shortSummary: In 1 Samuel 23, David seeks the Lord’s guidance to defend the city of Keilah from the Philistines and successfully rescues its inhabitants. Despite Saul’s pursuit and the betrayal by the Ziphites, David remains under God’s protection, strengthened by Jonathan’s encouragement and his own faithfulness.
timeline: c. 1050 BC - Early reign of Saul and David’s rise as a fugitive leader

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The anointed future king of Israel, leading his men in battle and seeking God’s direction while fleeing from Saul.

keyCharacters.name: Saul
keyCharacters.description: The current king of Israel who pursues David with the intent to capture or kill him.

keyCharacters.name: Abiathar
keyCharacters.description: The priest who brings the ephod to David, enabling him to inquire of the Lord.

keyCharacters.name: Jonathan
keyCharacters.description: Saul’s son who encourages and strengthens David’s faith, reaffirming the covenant between them.

keyCharacters.name: The Ziphites
keyCharacters.description: Residents of Ziph who betray David by informing Saul of his whereabouts.

definitions.definition: A sacred priestly garment used in Israel, often associated with seeking God’s guidance through the Urim and Thummim.
Flat surfaces where grain was separated from chaff, often targeted by enemies to disrupt food supply.
Fortified places or natural defenses where David and his men took refuge.
Meaning 'Rock of Division,' the place named after Saul’s interrupted pursuit of David due to the Philistine invasion.

outline.heading: David Defends Keilah
outline.description: David learns of the Philistine attack on Keilah and, after seeking God’s direction, leads his men to defeat the enemy and rescue the city, demonstrating his role as God’s chosen protector.

outline.heading: Saul’s Pursuit and David’s Escape
outline.description: Saul plans to trap David in Keilah, but through divine revelation and the use of the ephod, David discovers the city’s betrayal and escapes, showing God’s providential care.

outline.heading: David’s Wilderness Refuge and Jonathan’s Support
outline.description: David dwells in wilderness strongholds while Jonathan visits to encourage him, reaffirming their covenant and God’s protection over David’s future kingship.

outline.heading: Betrayal by the Ziphites and Saul’s Failed Pursuit
outline.description: The Ziphites inform Saul of David’s location, prompting a pursuit that is interrupted by a Philistine invasion, allowing David to escape to Engedi, highlighting God’s sovereign intervention.

application: Seek God’s guidance earnestly in times of uncertainty or danger, as David did before making decisions.
Trust in God’s protection even when facing betrayal or overwhelming opposition.
Encourage and strengthen fellow believers in their faith, following Jonathan’s example with David.
Remain obedient and faithful to God’s calling despite external threats and hardships.

keyVerses.text: Therefore David enquired of the LORD, saying, Shall I go and smite these Philistines? And the LORD said unto David, Go, and smite the Philistines, and save Keilah.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the importance of seeking God’s direct guidance before taking action.

keyVerses.text: And David abode in the wilderness in strong holds, and remained in a mountain in the wilderness of Ziph. And Saul sought him every day, but God delivered him not into his hand.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes God’s protection over David despite Saul’s persistent pursuit.

keyVerses.text: And he said unto him, Fear not: for the hand of Saul my father shall not find thee; and thou shalt be king over Israel, and I shall be next unto thee; and that also Saul my father knoweth.
keyVerses.significance: Jonathan’s encouragement reassures David of God’s plan and the certainty of his future kingship.

keyVerses.text: Wherefore Saul returned from pursuing after David, and went against the Philistines: therefore they called that place Selahammahlekoth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows God’s providential intervention in redirecting Saul’s focus and preserving David’s life.
